Solar panels actually work more efficiently in cooler climates.&nbsp; The panels retain heat and help melt snow more quickly.&nbsp; In addition, sunlight reflecting off snow on the ground can contribute to generating electricity during winter.</p></td></tr></tbody></table><p>&nbsp;</p>","rightText":null,"headerText":"Making connections"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":1,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"showRuler":0,"showRFB":1},"leftText":"<p>Read the next paragraphs and think about what they are telling you.<br />&nbsp;</p><table border=\"1\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-tableplain\" style=\"width: 90%;\"><tbody><tr><td><p><strong>Some folks worry that if we have a long stretch of stormy weather, they might be without electricity.</strong></p><p>No, Greg, because the vast majority of solar programs are tied to the electric grid.&nbsp; Ideally, you will produce what you need, but if you do not, you will continue to draw electricity from the grid as needed.</p></td></tr></tbody></table><p><br />If you <strong>connect</strong> this to the previous paragraph, what connection can you logically make?</p><p><jumc ju-mc=\"mc_86e7b547-d345-cdda-fe65-cc983ac43eef\" style=\"width: 200px; Here&#39;s an example:<br />&nbsp;</p><table border=\"1\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-tableplain ju-tight\" style=\"width: 90%;\"><tbody><tr><td><p>Thunderstorms develop in many ways and take many forms depending on the size of the cell that creates them and whether the cells are organized into a squall line.&nbsp; A cell, or a cloud that contains an updraft and a downdraft, is subject to a process called convection (the upward movement of warm air and the corresponding downward movement of cold air).&nbsp; A simple, short-lived storm is often the result of a single cell, while longer-lasting storms are often multicell storms, or storms that are composed of multiple cells that create prolonged rain and storms.&nbsp; As warm airs rises through the convection process, water vapor condenses (takes liquid form) and becomes cloud droplets.&nbsp; These droplets join together to become raindrops. When the rain mass suspended in the cloud becomes too heavy, the rain drops out of the cloud as precipitation--for example, as a sudden shower or rainstorm.&nbsp; The typical single cell storms lasts between 30 and 45 minutes, and it is often accompanied by lightning, which results from positive electrical charges interacting with negative electrical charges in the cloud.&nbsp; When the charges become large enough, the cloud sets off a spark.&nbsp; That spark is what we call lightning.</p></td></tr></tbody></table><p>&nbsp;</p>","rightText":null,"headerText":"Understanding complex topics"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":1,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"showRuler":0,"showRFB":1},"leftText":"<p>Active reading strategies can help!&nbsp; When you encounter complex reading material, break the reading into smaller pieces, each one a few sentences long.&nbsp; Then, concentrate on the shorter sections of the reading.<br /><br />Take your time.&nbsp; Expect to work slowly through challenging reading material.&nbsp; Plan to read it several times.&nbsp; Make notes of what you find or decide that each section of the reading means.<br /><br />There are a few techniques you can use as you read each section.<br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":null},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":0,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":1,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"showRuler":1,"showRFB":1},"leftText":"<p><strong>1.
